boardgame.name: Dominion: Storage Box
Tragekoffer Dominion
boardgame.description:
Google Translation, User Edited
THE storage for the full set of Dominion!
This is the case for Dominion; the Collector Case!

This case is made ​​of highly stable, high quality corrugated board.

The printed case has 5 compartments with drawers for all the Dominion cards. It fits the base cards and a small expansion (such as Alchemy, Prosperity, et al.) in the top drawer. Below are 3 drawers for larger expansions (26 slots. Be aware: Dark Ages has more cards than other expansions!). Finally, there is a drawer for playing boards and for promos and the blue edged randomizers. The spacing in the case is so well designed that even cards with protective covers fit.

The case comes assembled with a sturdy handle. The drawers conveniently organize about 2,500 cards.

Hans im Gluck Description (Original German)
DIE Aufbewahrung für wahre Dominion-Könner
Dies ist der Koffer für Dominion. Oder auch der Collectors Case!

Was bieten die Koffer?

Beide Koffer sind aus sehr stabiler, hochwertiger Wellpappe hergestellt.

Dieser bedruckte Koffer hat 5 Fächer. In diesem Fall ist er mit Dominion-Schubladen ausgestattet. Dabei passen die Basiskarten und eine kleine Erweiterung (Alchemisten, Reiche Ernte) in die obere Schublade. Es folgen 3 Schubladen für Editionen oder große Erweiterungen (26 Steckplätze. Vorsicht, die Erweiterung "Dark Ages" hat mehr Karten als die bisherigen Erweiterungen!). Schließlich gibt es eine Schublade für Tableaus, die Karten mit blauem Rand und Promokarten. Die Fächer für die Karten sind so groß, dass auch Karten mit Schutzhüllen hineinpassen.
Der Koffer wird zusammengebaut mit einem stabilen Griff geliefert.

Zusätzlich gibt es Schubladen, die zusammen ca. 2.500 Karten fassen.

boardgame.name: Malifaux: Ten Thunders Archers
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

A long ranged minion that can hit hard from a distance at a medium cost. This minion can be hired by any Ten Thunders Crew. This Minion is best used away from the main fighting. It has some very good tricks to get shots in but only has bash in melee. It has a couple of good zero point actions to bolster its attacks and also a 1 point action called Take Aim. This is a (1) action focus strike giving you a positive flip on your shot but can only be used once per activation.

The best thing about this model is that its ranged attacks are usually further than an opposing minions range. This enables you to move it in to place to cover your melee fighters. Remember to use the Threading the Needle ability by moving it with something like a Torokage as it can effectively shoot through the model to the enemy. Remeber the Take Aim will usually be your first shot and then decide whether you need to use Reading the Wind if you have low cards in your hand or if the model you are shooting at is in cover or the Spell Yajiri with the second attack to bolster its damage or cause non living models to slow down.

boardgame.name: Malifaux: Rail Crew
Malifaux: Rail Crew – Mei Feng Box Set
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

Mei Feng is a melee caster. She excels at fighting multiple opponents, being able to dart into combat using her own constructs as stepping stones, once engaged she can move from opponent to opponent laying down damage and burning tokens. Mei Feng can combo her spells and strikes together into chains, which though card intensive allow her to pull off some impressive feats.

When starting a Mei Feng crew, you will have to buy the Rail Crew box set (Mei is not available to purchase individually at present). This allows you to build a crew for either Arcanists, or 10 Thunders, which will affect which other models you may wish to purchase. The Rail Crew contains Mei Feng, Kang, the Emberling, and 3 Rail Workers. This is all that you need to play either an Arcanist crew, or 10 thunders crew at the 25 soulstone level.

Mei can hire fire gamin, metal gamin, Willie the demolitionist, and a Rail Golem regardless of which faction she is used with. She may never use any models which have the frozen heart ability.

boardgame.name: Malifaux: Izamu
Malifaux: Izamu – The Armor
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki

Not a minion at all, but a suit of armour resurrected at the whim of its master. Izamu is an ancient blood thirsty warlord that lived during the old days of the Katanaka clan that Yan Lo was also a member of. Today, he is called upon by Yan Lo to bring death to all those that oppose him.

Izamu's mobility is pretty unimpressive with a bog standard 4/6 move/charge and only one mobility trick to speak of which is Shove Aside (allows Izamu to nove through ht1 and 2 models). He does have a very respectable 3" melee range though. He also benefits greatly from mobility tricks given by other models, be it the Soul Porter with Empower Ancestor, Toshiro with Tenki no Juden or Molly and Imbue Vigor.

Now we are cooking with gas! Izamus is a melee monster packing Melee Expert, a base + to all his damage flips, a respectable combat of 6 on a range 3 weapon and a very nice damage spread of 3/4/6. That damage spread is his edge compared to the dead rider, Izamu can nuke a most low mid cost models in one severe strike. He also has a cute trigger with his Daodao that lets his weapon be considered magical if you get a tome which is nice since it's a suit ressers don't use much and is always nice to have that possibility when facing spirit heavy crews.

Ironically, Izamu does not even have an armour rating. Instead he is an Object 2, which is actually better. This means he is reducing 2 damage from anything heading his way unless it ignores object and for now, very few things actually do that. His tankiness doesn't end there, he is also immune to influence, so WP strikes do nothing against him. He is able to nullify enemy triggers if he cheats fate on his defense and resist flips, the suit of the card he uses to cheat will not cause any of the triggers the enemy may be packing, so Lady Justice getting you down? cheat with a Ram and yeah, you may be taking the hit, but there is no onslaught or critical strike going in with it.

boardgame.name: Malifaux: Oiran
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

Oiran are the Ten Thunders escorts in Malifaux. They understand the power of words, and find their place in the city by whispering secrets and lies, twisting others to their objectives.

Oiran only have their Concealed Weapon, which is close range. If Oiran is Harmless when they make a Concealed Weapon Strike, you can choose to add a positive flip to either the attack or damage flip, which helps them out a lot.

Oiran are Harmless, and have two ways to regain Harmless after they have lost it, (1) Sultry, and a Cb trigger for killing a model with Concealed Weapons.
Expert Defense improves the benefits of taking a Defensive Stance, giving Oiran an extra positive flip, and only reduces walk and charge by -1/-1.

The Defensive Dance trigger allows Oiran to assume a Defensive Stance after casting Tranquil Dance for a 6+ mask. If you have the card to spare, this allows you to buff your crew or debuff the opponent, if in range, while still protecting Oiran.
If fighting a Wp duel heavy list, keeping models around Oiran can be very useful. She can (0) Appealing to give Wp +1, and (1) Tranquil Dance can give a positive flip to Wp Resist Duels to models within 6".

boardgame.name: Malifaux: Rail Golem
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

A powerful model that uses Burning Tokens to power its spells, abilities and attacks. It can be the heavy hitter many crews lack, and even though expensive, you are getting a massive piece for only 9 (or 10) SS.

The Rail Golem works well with models that can put Burning Tokens on it, but it is self sufficient enough to work with any crew.

The Rail Golem has very significant offensive abilities. Its melee weapon has a good reach, is Paired, and causes grievous damage, and it can use Burning Tokens to get positive twists to attack or damage, or an extra melee attack.

The main "trick" with the Rail Golem is to balance out how it accumulates and uses Burning Tokens. Often, you will need to balance between increasing attacks in a short-term way (by increasing attacks and damage flips, or getting an extra attack), healing up (by burning all tokens for 1 Wd of healing each), or saving them up to Reactivate (which costs 5 tokens, but can be very powerful.)

boardgame.name: Malifaux: Nekima, The Dark Sibling
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

Nekima is a dual role minion with specialized abilities to provide support, and hard hitting melee power. She does however lack, in the resilience department, and costs quite a lot of SS to bring on the table.

Since this model’s release, there was an important change to the Nephilim Heart ability, restricting its application to Terror Tots and Young Nephilims only. This prevented some abuse from the synergy Nekima had with other models, but also severely limited her support abilities to specific minions.

With the latest FAQ update, Wyrd stated that “Nekima will get her turn” so we can expect that somewhere down the future, she will get a touch up, but there is no way to know to what extent this will affect her.

Nekima is quite specific with her synergies. She works well with the typical Nephilim growth list or other Young Nephilim and Terror Tot based lists. However intended, Nekima’s support abilities have short range, and her melee prowess is only really useable if she’s protected from harm.

Nekima plays hand-in-hand with growth lists, because she has means to provide blood counters. Rather than draining blood when she kills, she gets a count whenever a living or undead model dies within 3". This occurs automatically, and even if another model used its Drain Blood, such as a Terror Tot. Remember that most Nephilim are alive and she will get a counter from them too when they die.

boardgame.name: Galaxy Defenders
boardgame.description:
Galaxy Defenders is a sci-fi cooperative, tactical battle game in which 1-5 players fight together against an oncoming alien menace. Each player takes control of one or more agents with unique powers to defend the planet from the alien invasion. Gameplay revolves around a tactical combat system, using custom ten-sided dice. Each player sequentially plays his Agent turn and then one Aliens turn. Players carry out their turns [agent and aliens] in clockwise order until the last player finishes his Aliens turn. Once done, the game passes to the Event phase that will bring the players to the next round. Players may choose up to five agents:


Marine: Coming from U.S. Special Forces, the Marine is an excellent soldier who can manage different combat situations, especially multiple enemies.
Biotech: The Biotech is the most technologically adept agent in service. He can use Nano-Technology to heal wounds or control war drones.
Infiltrator: A deadly and stealthy agent. This lethal specialist prefers hiding in the shadows. She has fast movement and good short-range combat ability.
Sniper: A silent sharpshooter and expert in camouflage and ranged combat. The sniper has average movement and excellent long-range firepower.
Hulk: The Hulk was a successful mercenary and now is one of the best agents; although slow, he enjoys an extraordinary resistance to damage and has high firepower.


There is no "Alien player" in Galaxy Defenders; instead, the aliens are controlled by the game system itself, through an artificial intelligence system based on two types of cards:


Alien cards, which define the behavior of each different alien and detail its skills and combat abilities.
Close Encounter cards, which are used at the beginning of each alien turn to determine which aliens activate.


The combination of a unique AI for each alien species and the uncertainty about alien activation in a turn provides a realistic simulation of the chaos of battle and a sophisticated challenge for the players. Since having more agents brings more alien activations for the aliens, the turn structure allows the level of difficulty to scale dynamically based on the number of agents in play. If agents die during the game, the system "recalibrates" the difficulty to a reasonable and enjoyable level, so you still have a chance to complete the mission.

The battle for Earth will be carried out in a series of twelve missions organized in a completely story-driven campaign. Mission events influence future games in two different ways:


Each mission has multiple endings, and the outcome of any mission will change the flow of the story.
The agents gain experience during the missions. This experience transforms a good soldier into a perfect Galaxy Defender agent with multiple skills, basic and improved tactics, and the ability to use new devices, improved human weapons, and Alien technology.


With the downloadable Galaxy Defenders: Alien Mind variant, you can transform the game into a competitive affair, with one player becoming the alien mastermind and controlling the alien army and the card in play, attempting to thwart each mission undertaken by the Agents. To do this, the alien player completes his own game objectives, obtaining new "alien signals" that can be teleported onto the battlefield. This variant, which allows for play with up to six players, can be used in a single mission or for a whole campaign of Galaxy Defenders. Using Alien Mind may increase the game difficulty and is suggested only for expert players.

The Chemical Chaos promotional expansion pack adds 14 new Compounds and 1 additional Lab Fire to your game of Compounded (marked by chemical element symbol in corner of cards). These mix in more strategic play and chaos to the game.

Game play then continues per the normal rules.

boardgame.name: Malifaux: Lilith Avatar of Nature's Malevolence
boardgame.description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

Lilith's Avatar is unique in that she interacts very heavily with terrain, and can make significant changes to woods terrain and the board as a whole. She creates and spreads woods terrain, and then makes that woods terrain very scary for her enemies. She retains most of the abilities of her pre-Avatar form, though many become more woods-dependent. Lilith also gains some very useful long-range attacks and damage effects, which can assist in pushing opponents around and controlling board position.

In Avatar Form, Lilith suddenly needs to worry about two things that didn't matter as much before, woods terrain and Blood Tokens.

Woods Terrain: An overwhelming portion of Lilith's Actions, Spells, and Attacks work only in woods terrain, or work much better in woods terrain. Lilith wants to stay near the woods, and to keep her enemies near the woods too. Place your initial woods terrain carefully, keeping near any objective locations and any likely spots for enemies to congregate. Be sure your Illusionary Forest is in a good place, too, before you Manifest Lilith's Avatar. You can spread woods further from these existing locations, using Lilith's Sanguine Proliferation spell. This requires a 9 card or better, and suits don't matter, so you should plan to have a card in hand for it in case your flip isn't enough. This growth can seem very slow, however, since you can only expand by 3" for every action, so it's usually best to do this only if you're setting up an immediate attack on an opponent who's not quite in reach of the forest on Lilith's turn. Note also that Sanguine Proliferation costs a Blood Token, which can be in short supply.

Gaining Blood Tokens: If you're fighting against living or Undead opponents, Lilith can usually gain a Blood Token every time something dies: anyone killed by her Nature's Revenge spell, or killed within 8" of her and in base contact with a woods terrain, generates a Blood Token. Note that you also generate Blood Tokens when your own models are killed within 8" of Lilith if they're in base contact with a woods terrain. Lilith's most likely crews (Nephilim and Waldgeists) are all considered living, so this may provide some benefit or at least consolation. She can also gain a Blood Token when she kills a living or Undead unit by using Drain Blood, but this is a (0) Action so she can only use it once per round. Note, though, that if your enemy has a lot of Constructs, Nightmares, Objects, Spirits, or Soulless models, these won't give you any Blood Tokens so it may not be worth Manifesting.

Spending Blood Tokens: While pre-Manifest Lilith only really keeps her Blood Tokens to feed her young or try to meet a scheme for VP, in Avatar form she has tremendous need of Blood Tokens. Avatar Lilith uses Blood Tokens to use her Erupting Underbrush mass melee attack, to expand the woods with her Sanguine Proliferation spell (though she can use Blood Tokens from nearby minions within 6" instead for this), and to attack units with her Nature's Revenge spell (though this may also give her Blood Tokens back, possibly generating a profit if she kills a lot of wounded minions). On top of this, she can also use Blood Tokens to grow and mature her Nephilim. The demand and uses of Blood Tokens are quite high for Lilith, so take some care in choosing the right way to spend a Token. A good general rule is: if it's going to kill at least one enemy model, it's worth spending a Blood Token, especially if that model is living or Undead. Otherwise, the Blood Token is probably better spent growing a Terror Tot.

Card Flow Control: Avatar Lilith retains her Rush of Magic Ability and Bloody Fate trigger, so you will often pull a card and discard it during play. This doesn't give you more control cards, but it can be a helpful way of raising the average value of your cards and helping you find the Mask (or occasionally Crows) cards you need. Remember to use these card flow effects, since they will help refine your hand.

From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

Ophelia is a gunfighter, capable of dishing out good amounts of damage from a distance. She leads a crew of her most trusted kin on raids against human settlements, using her prowess with her pistolas to bring back loot. All of her kin are companioned to Ophelia, allowing them to activate together and get the first strike! She is also the only Henchman that Som'er may take, and she is key to his Crew.

However, Ophelia is more than just a trigger finger. She also has a host of abilities to enhance the gremlins around her, making her a fun and useful tool to any gremlin list, whether it is led by Som'er or herself.

Ophelia is an excellent leader to begin your Malifaux collection. She is versatile, intuitive, and just generally good and fun. Also, all of the models which you purchase for her are fantastic models for Som'er, and he is a good master to expand out to when you want a few more options.

boardgame.name: Spanish Civil War: The World War of Spain
boardgame.description:
With a great deal of support, a coalition within the Spanish Military (called Nationalists) declared their revolt in July 1936. The Nationalists allied with Conservative, Fascist, Monarchist and Catholic groups to “save” Spain. The democratically elected government of Spain (called Republicans) gathered Left-wing Republicans, Socialists, Communists and Anarchists together to fight these “Nationalist” insurgents. The Nationalists were primarily supported by Nazi Germany, Fascist Italy, and the dictatorship of Portugal. The Republicans were primarily supported by Communist Russia and Mexico. Other countries remained neutral and followed official policies of non-intervention. Many neutral country’s citizens however made their way to Spain to volunteer in the International Brigades and fight for Republican Spain.
In Spain the sides are clear. Can the red tide be stopped in Spain? Can fascism be given its first real defeat here? Whatever happens, the conflict in Spain will echo on into the coming war that will likely engulf the world.

Winning the War:
Every territory has resources of men and material to gain or lose until final victory is in sight. On your turn you build, maneuver, and deploy your land and air forces to gain territory for yourself, and deny it to your enemy. In a civil war you fight until one side surrenders. In Spanish Civil War: The World War of Spain, this is the case. You fight until one side surrenders or until one side controls every province of mainland Spain.

boardgame.name: Runestar: Tactical Fantasy Warfare
boardgame.description:
Runestar is a D12 mass-fantasy system, designed for use with 28mm miniatures. It has a dynamic turn sequence to create a sense of simultaneous combat and balanced play rewards strategy over luck. Players choose their own armies from one of twelve army lists; fielding hosts of infantry, archers, cavalry and skirmishers, supported by war-beasts, artillery, air cavalry and superheavies, led by their heroes and mages. With over two hundred unique unit types the variety is endless.

All units in Runestar are made using a mathematical formula, so all army lists start from a level-playing field. However, there is plenty of style to go with the substance, and players can expect characterful special rules and random crazy stuff too. Its not quite as balanced as chess, but then it isn't designed to be!

The objective of each game of Runestar varies - from headhunting missions to slay enemy heroes to all out clashes of force; from small elite forces ambushing vast hordes to take and hold scenarios; from epochal sieges with giant hosts to subtle skirmishes of ten or twenty warriors in places deep and dark.

Players can set their battles on the nodeworld Goragaia or in extra-planar realms, where the laws of Nature hold less sway. With five Era's worth of fantastical history, players can re-fight legendary battles in the Runestar canon or forge the future in the fires of war.

The one-roll combat system (attacker strength + defender weakness = to-hit roll) ensures that games play swiftly, and the mighty D12 allows for plenty of variation between units whilst keeping things slick.

The Rune-magick system is unique. Mages combine rune cards to form spells, stacking the abilities of different runes on top of each other to create their own chants. Players must use their own initiative to cast magick effectively, and the creative possibilities are boundless.

Magick items are extremely rare, and most champions must rely on runic blades which need to be charged by mages to have any special effects. Mages also have access to Arcanes - runic staves and talismans which cast special spells when they are charged with certain runes, providing more of a tactical advantage than one of brute might.

Runestar is set on the nodeworld Goragaia in its Fifth Era and is as much a saga as it is a game. Forces metaphysical clash against each other in a world steeped in ancient history, echoes of dead gods, runic-magick and the mystery of the Runestar itself. Caught between a titanic federation of human realms, the Sivan Alliance, and the Undying Legions of psychotic monarchs, the Symbol Kings, the factions of Goragaia know that only one force will remain standing by the end of the Fifth Era...

boardgame.name: Trilania
boardgame.description:
A fast-paced, multiplayer, strategy war game that utilizes custom dice. Assemble your army, build, develop, and conquer.

Welcome to the realm of Trilania, a world that has been ripped apart by magic in many ways...
First, where once the planet was whole, a disruption in the balance of magic caused it to be divided into three layers: the Lowlands, which is the main land; the Midlands, and, suspended by magic above the Lowlands, the Highlands.
Second, the land has been divided by war for over a century. Many of the Highland races believed their gods set them above the rest of the world, and it was their destiny to rule the lower races. Most of the Midlands strived for neutrality, seeking to open trade with the Highlands and the Lowlands. The Lowlands were divided into two main groups, those who sought only equality, and those who wanted to overthrow the Highland races. Some races, with the use of magic, altered themselves to resemble their animalistic gods, and the other races, realizing that this gave them physical and tactical advantages, followed suit. You must now choose which race or races you will command, lead them into battle, and form temporary alliances as you see fit. But choose your allies wisely and watch your back, because in the end, there can only be one victor. Always remember, the best laid strategy can sometimes go awry. Let the Dice Fly High!

Game-play is pretty simple. Choose the team of dice which is kind of like building a typical card deck, except with dice. Each dice costs a certain amount Team Points (TP). You have 140 TP to build your team.

A Teams consist of 2 types of dice Units and Buildings:

Units - units do not have a TP cost. Each unit is worth 'X'amount of Man Power (MP)'X' is equal to the units level. MP is used to build addition buildings and upgrades.
Level 1 units: Tend to be your weaker men
Level 2 units: Are stronger then level 1 units of course

Buildings
War Camps: produce level 1 and 2 units
Secondary Buildings: give you various advantages through upgrades and elite level units

Objective: build units to destroy your opponents ability to produce troops.

boardgame.name: The Creature
boardgame.description:
THEME You and your friends are researchers working at an undisclosed facility operated and owned by the shadowy pharmaceutical company PharmaDyn. There you and your fellow lab workers have been tasked with studying a parasitic alien organism found frozen deep in the Arctic ice. To everyone's horror, the specimen turns up missing and anyone could be the infectious Creature's host! As a Human, try to reveal the Creature's identity before it infects everyone and escapes the quarantine.

GOAL The Humans, represented by the Immune, must identify and eliminate the Creature before the Creature and his Infected outnumber them.

GAMEPLAY The game is meant to be played over a weeks time, or roughly one day for every one person playing the game.

On the first day each person is dealt an Identity card from the deck, two of which must be the Creature and the Immune. The person who draws the Immune must immediately reveal their Identity to the group, whereas everyone else keeps their Identity a secret.

Once the Identities have been established, and the Immune has revealed themselves to the group, the game officially begins. At this point everyone is free to go about their business. Now the Creature begins his mission. Once a day, including the first, the Creature may approach one of the other players, shake their hand, and state "You have been Infected" to convert them to the Creature's side. The Creature may only do this once per day, but doing so will increase their numbers, and ultimately bring the Infected closer to victory.

On each day following the first, the group will get back together for a few moments to discuss what has happened since they last met. After everyone has had an opportunity to speak, they will collectively vote on who they think the Creature is. The person with the most votes against them must reveal their Identity and are eliminated from the game. The Creature and any of his Infected are still part of the voting process, because as far as anyone else knows they are Human.

The Humans win if the can eliminate the Creature during the vote. If the Immune is eliminated however, the Creature and his Infected are victorious.

FINAL The Creature should be played with at least 8 people, and playing with more people is almost always a better experience. The game includes other unique Identities, in addition to the Immune and Creature, that may be added to the game for more fun and chaos.

boardgame.name: The Quest for Piptwynn's Scroll
boardgame.description:
User Summary

The The Quest for Piptwynn's Scroll is a tabletop miniatures game that pits two players against each other to obtain Piptwynn's Scroll, an artifact of great importance, that can be found on the top of Star Snag Crag. The object of the game is to reach the top of the Crag, retrieve the Scroll, and then make it off the Crag again. The game board is defined as a series 49 four inch squares arranged in four tiers. The top tier is the peak of Star Snag Crag.

Each player controls a team, or Quad, made up of 4 different specialists, selected from the 8 possible types listed in the game. Some types focus on mobility, others on combat, and some, like the Beastmastr [sic], level the playing field with unusual abilities. These character types also rely on items (magical & non-magical) to give them an edge in certain situations.

Each turn the players perform game actions in a set order of phases: Activation, Movement, Exploration and Occurrences (weather effects or wandering monsters), Conflict Resolution, and Evening (a time of healing and recharging). Both players act simultaneously so occasionally members of one Quad will end up in conflict with each other quite by accident. Random game elements can also send creatures or primitives to attack members of a Quad. Terrain effects are randomly determined the first time the member of a Quad enters a new square. These effects can produce anything from a Refreshing Spring to a Dragon Nest.

Unlike most miniatures game, death isn't a feature of Piptwynn's Scroll. When one side wins a conflict, the other side is driven away. Since this is fundamentally a race to the peak of Star Snag Crag, getting pushed back on any given turn can make the difference between winning and losing. In this way the game is more family-friendly than the many miniatures games that focus on death and dismemberment.

The rulebook also contains several rules variants, including set up a larger board for tournament play. Also included are reproducible sheets, charts, tokens, etc., along with tips on how to paint miniatures and how to build a proper three-dimensional game board. (Players must provide their own miniatures, a playing surface--which can be simple map or more traditional war game terrain, and a set of polyhedral dice)

There were several planned follow-up games for this title, including an RPG crossover. None of them seem to have ever come to fruition.

boardgame.name: Robots on the Line
boardgame.description:
You're one of the lucky robot factory workers invited to an exclusive event. Your job? Picking refurbished or out-of-date parts to build robots that meet eager buyers' requirements. Sell your completed robots to earn points and achieve certain bonuses to earn even more points — but hurry because other players may be building a robot to sell to the same buyer first. Can you outsmart your opponents and assemble a four-wheeler robot with two heads, or a robot with six eyes and four hands before they do?

In Robots on the Line, robot parts move down two conveyor belts. Players take turns pulling robot parts (heads, bases, arms, hands, batteries, antennas and magnets). Not all robot parts can be taken, however. The line you're pulling from must be switched to ON. Robot parts that aren't taken will be discarded onto the junk pile. Players can pay a dollar to go through the junk pile or they can pay a dollar to turn ON/OFF switches. As players take robot parts, they build robots in front of them. Players can build up to four robots in a game. Trading is always allowed.

To finish a robot it must have a torso, a head, and a base with all other segments off the torso ended with the other parts. While you're building, you'll want to look to the buyers to meet their requirements. A requirement might be a robot with four eyes, or a robot that has no wheels, or a robot with three hands. If you meet a buyer's requirement, you sell it for money. If you meet the bonuses, like medical, war, or cleaning, you get even more money. The game ends when all tiles are off the line or when a player has built 3 robots. The player with the most money wins.

boardgame.name: Noddy's Birthday Party Game
boardgame.description:
A rather complicated board for the age group that would normally enjoy a Noddy related game.

Each player chooses a character and the associated playing piece. There are 6 face-down counters and when you set off along the track you must take one. Turn it over and that tells you which present you are taking to Noddy's house (example present might be a cake).

The first track to move along is the red one. If you land on white numbered squares, they will help you. If you land on black numbered squares then that will be a hazard. However the game at this point is a little different to normal Goose-type games. When arriving on a hazard square, refer to the list in the rules. Hazards relate to the presents. So, if you were carrying the cake, then a hazard for any other present would not apply.

After reaching the end of the red track, you start moving along the letters that spell Noddy (located in the centre of the board). You must reach the end of the fifth letter Y and then set off on the return journey which will end on the letter N.

Finally you move a long the white circles to Noddy's house. However, on this path there are three circles that feature two colours. If you land on one of these and your counter is one of these two colours, then you have to wait until the player with other colour reaches this circle. That wait could be a long one which might well bore the player affected. I guess the designer wanted to make a game that allowed the back-markers to catch up, which is fair enough.

The winner is the first to arrive at Noddy's house.

boardgame.name: よんろのご: IGO puzzle
boardgame.description:
「よんろのご」は、囲碁界のエース・張 栩（ちょう う）棋士が考案した、囲碁のルールを使ったパズルです。盤を大きな木に、白黒の石を赤と青のりんごに変えて、頭を使いながら楽しく問題を解いていきます。
家族や友達と遊びながら問題を解くうちに、「石を取る」という囲碁の基本的なルールや論理的な思考を養うことができます。

Roughly translated from the back of the box:

"4 by 4 Go" is a puzzle game designed by pro Go player Chang Hsu (AKA Cho U 9 dan) for his four-year-old daughter, which is based on the rules of Go. The name comes from there being 4 lines to play on, each line being called "RO" (1ro, 2ro, 3ro, etc) and "YON" meaning the number four.

Instead of the black and white stones common to Go, the game uses red and green discs resembling apples and the board has been made to look like a tree. Included is a booklet of puzzles questions for children to think about and arrange on the board to try solving with friends and family.

Once the first step of basic challenges has been completed, a 2 player Go-like game called "Stone Capture" (ishi o toru) can be played. [Players take turns placing apples (stones), capturing each others stones until either the opponent has no place to play or the board is dominated by one color.]

The box set includes:
15 Red Apples
15 Green Apples
Question Booklet
4x4 Go Board

boardgame.name: REVOLVIQA Blue
boardgame.description:
REVOLVIQA

RevolvIQa, the revolving game series debuted in Nürnberg Toy Fair 2013. It’s basis is an innovation: playing piece supported revolving mechanism. The supporter is a playing piece onto which a constituted bottom surface in the middle of the revolving device is laid upon. A playing piece supported revolving device can make 6 playing pieces step at once.
RevolvIQa Red and RevolvIQa Blue are two independent games, packed into independent boxes, however these ones are intending to be an overture of revolving game series.
In a RevolvIQa box there are 3 individual games: 2 pcs. revolving puzzle games in varied difficulty levels (1 player) and 1 pc. revolving board game (2 players). Playing adventure and rules are varied, however a.m. structure is the same in both RevolvIQa boxes.
Play with revolving puzzles first:
the basic idea here is to have different coloured balls as a „pixel” of a pic on a playing field. The playing field plate is removable and exchangable. It has a hexagonal shape and it is hole-punched at 37 places in bee-cells pattern. It is to be put onto a basic board having 37 spheric recesses in the same pattern area. After pouring the required balls onto field, revolve until all the coloured balls match with the colours of the graphic. Starting with any ball arrangement results solution! A „Fox” and a „Galaxy” in RevolvIQa Red, a „Parachute” and a „Birthday” in RevolvIQa Blue is available as main theme on graphics of the playing fields.
Play with board games next:
There are equal starting chance arrangements for both players and one after the other order playable games by immediate revolving in both RevolvIQa board games.
Player wins, who revolves 5 in one row of its chosen coloured balls at first: that’s the board game about in RevolvIQa Red. Defeat arrives as magic touch in most of the cases. It’s name: „COLORICA-5”.
Player wins in board game of RevolvIQa Blue, whose all chosen 4 ferries are able to cross the sea first, or the one, whose opponent can’t revolve rule-wise anymore. It’s wintertime and some areas in the sea is frozen (white balls on the board). Revolving rules: revolve on water only (support on dark blue balls only), at least one of revolving player’s ferries shall change place during revolving action, the opponent’s can be revolved at the same time, but only if opponent’s previous revolving action took place elsewhere. Captivating and exciting. It’s name: „FERRY”.


REVOLVIQA Blue
3 games in the box: Parachute, Birthday, Ferry

Revolving puzzle and board games that are developing creativity and logical and strategic skills for 1 or 2 players, children or adults.

Parachute

Revolving puzzle games that are developing creativity and logical skills for 1 player, children or adults. Revolve so that the colored balls could get into their position!

Birthday

Revolving puzzle games that are developing creativity and logical skills for 1 player, children or adults. Revolve so that the colored balls could get into their position!

Ferry

Games developing logical and strategic skills for two players. The purpose of the game is that one of the players should get all 4 balls (ferries) of his to the other side by revolving them.

boardgame.name: Interface Zero 2.0: Full Metal Cyberpunk
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:



FULL METAL CYBERPUNK!

In a not-so-distant future, the world has been ravaged by global warming, subjected to the horrors of nuclear war and natural disaster, witnessed the collapse of the mightiest nation in the history of the world, and the rise of other nations to take its place. In East Asia, the Bear and the Dragon battle for control of the resource-rich continent, and an emergent A.I. known only as Charon has destabilized the whole of Europe, sparking revolution and chaos not seen since the Second World War.

On the North American continent, the prospect of conflict once again rears its ugly head as terrorist bombings in Atlantica, bring the nation to the brink of war with the North American Coalition. Is this the work of Charon, as well, or are other forces moving behind the scenes? Only time will tell.

Science has hacked the genome, unlocking the secrets of DNA to facilitate the creation of new breeds of human; genetic hybrids, human 2.0, and even simulacrum— a slave race grown in amniotic vats and sold on the open market. Cybernetic technology has reached the point where those with the money and the will to do so, can become living machines. Computer science has grown by leaps and bounds as well.

Dubbed Interface Zero by those who created it, the Tendril Access Processor—or TAP—downloads the Global DataNet and Hyper Reality directly into the minds of billions of users across the solar system, bringing the world an unparalleled level of interconnectivity, and danger. Malware plagues the Deep, and hackers manipulate the Tendril Access Processor to upload malicious virii, steal secrets, and even the identities of the unwary.

This is the world in 2090, omae; let’s hope you survive it.

Interface Zero 2.0 is a cyberpunk game powered by the Savage Worlds game system. Play bioroids, full-metal cyborgs, vat-grown simulacra, genetic hybrids, Human 2.0, and even androids! Hack the world around you with our revised hacking rules, or take control of a drone and lay down some fire-support for your team! Get cybered with new cybernetics using our Fast Furious and Fun rules!

A Guide to Portraying Elves as Fey

In myth, legend, and faerie tale, elves were not just another race competing with humans for land, waging war against orcs, and joining reluctant halflings to destroy coveted artifacts. They were something else; they were fey.

If you have a desire to play a different type of elf, one closer to nature and further from humans, Fringe Races: Elves is what you?ve been waiting for! Four new elven races. Though the names might look familiar, the elves do not. The light elves are the knights of the fey. The dark elves are the anti-heroes that radiate fear. The gray elves are of mixed blood between the two. Half-elves are not half-breeds with human lineage, but shorter, mischievous elves.
A look at elven realms, culture, society, and courts based on the new races.
Three new classes just for elves. These classes are adaptations on three of the core classes, allowing the elves to progress as elves, and not a cultural variant of humans.

Elven Masterwork weapons and armor.
Elf-shot.
8 new feats, 3 of which are supernatural.

boardgame.name: King of Crime: Bootleg Edition
boardgame.description:
2-6 player game, 15-20 minute game play. Players are the bosses of their families in the 1930s gangster era. Players hire thugs, bookies and torpedos to help them gain control of the various rackets in the city. Card play weakens/enhances family strengths during the game. The major twist is the HIT die, played during a racket round, where every character is a target!

Mature themes (nothing you couldn't read about in any Time-Life book from the library), recommended for 12+ years.

From the designer of Battle of the bands, Backstage Pass and Portable Adventures card games.

Players (families) battle each other to control a set number of rackets, 2 of one kind of racket or 3 of any kind racket. You build your family using thug, bookie and torpedo cards, collectively known as mug cards. Their point value is your power during rackets. When a racket card is being fought over, the players all roll a HIT die (1d6); any opponent mugs in play that match your die roll (a die is printed on the mug cards), those cards are either flipped-unusable during this round, or discarded. The die roll is then added to the remaining value of your mugs in play, highest score wins the contract. But, you must have a mug who can control that racket, otherwise it is discarded. Family cards are played during non racket rounds to help your family or hinder the opposition.

boardgame.name: Leapfrog
boardgame.description:
Leapfrog is an alquerque-style game played on a square board of 97 spaces in a complex pattern. Each player has a Frog King and 8 Frog Pawns and the winner is the first player to get their Frog King to the central space.

Each player on their turn moves one piece a series of "leaps" — each leap being over exactly one occupied or unoccupied space. If the final leap is over a friendly piece then the player must immediately make another move with that piece. If the final leap is over an opponent's piece then the turn passes to that opponent who must make a move with that piece.

Leapfrog was published in issue 7 of the Games and Puzzles Journal.

boardgame.name: Das Bienenspiel
boardgame.description:
The game board represents a honeycomb in the bee hive. The queen rests in the middle of the brood nest (brown cells) surrounded by her royal household. The colored cells above the brood nest show stored pollen (inside the pollen field there are yellow and brown pollen cells).
Yet above the pollen field the honey cells are located (yellow cells). The honeycomb is occupied by the queen and several workers and drones. The smallest bees are workers.

In Das Bienenspiel players try to get 3 cards of honey and 3 cards of pollen. This is achieved by reaching either honey or pollen cells and claiming one. After each claim the player pawn has to return to the central brood nest unless he is able to hit a spot with a drone which allows the player to immediately turn around and go for another card.

Players have to move the full roll amount and must not enter cells which are occupied by bees or other player pawns.
Player with the full set of 6 cards (3+3) need to return to the queen cell to win the game.

Let the Wonders of the Ages Inspire You!

Few elements of fantasy roleplaying are as rife with possibility and potential as are artifacts, those ancient and unpredictable items of potent magics. boardgame.name: LEGO Chima CHI Battles
boardgame.description:
Set in the world of LEGO's Legends of Chima theme, the CHI Battles game system involves racing two LEGO vehicles — called "speedorz" — against one another to score "chi." If you win the dexterity part of a round, you then draw a card and select the attribute to use for attack. You can optionally spend one chi to add a sum to your score. Your competitor compares their score to yours and the winner claims two chi. The first player to reach six chi wins.

Different LEGO kits add different characters to the system, with their own speedorz, sets of character cards, and different buildable dexterity challenges.

boardgame.name: In The Club
boardgame.description:
Join the party with this tongue in cheek card game. Impress the ladies with crazy dances, exotic drinks and cheesy pick-up lines.

Players draw five "move" cards, a mixture of pick-up lines, dances, name-drops and outfits and cock-block cards. Then, players choose a location in the club to "make their move".

Locations include:
The Bar - players may exchange "move" cards for drink cards and play drink cards as well as other move cards.
The Dance Floor - players get a bonus to "dance moves" but cannot play name-drops or pick-up lines.
The VIP - players exchange a move card for entry, but receive a bonus for name drop cards. All other move cards can be played.
The Balcony - players get bonuses to pick-up lines and can play all other move types except dance moves.
The Bathroom - players can draw back up to 5 move cards.

The player who makes the best move, as scored by the total point value of all move cards made that round, impresses the lady that round. The next round, a new lady is eligible to impress, and the game continues until the lady total equals the winning total as determined by the number of players.

boardgame.name: Pax East Wizard Duel
boardgame.description:
Wizard Duel is a card game being played at the 2013 Penny Arcade Expo East. Players join one of 3 schools and roam the convention looking for other wizards to duel, and fight with a deck containing Bolt, Burst and Shield spells.
When you meet a rival wizard, call out a gravitas-laden challenge that will shake the heavens with it's fury (but not too loud). Each wizard will then select a card from his or her deck and reveal them dramatically at the same time.

A Bolt is a quick spell that strikes first to defeat the more complex Blast.
A Blast effects a large area and will easily circumvent a Shield
A Shield spell creates a wall of force that can ward off any Bolt.

The wizard with the victorious spell is... victorious! If wizards cast the same spell, they strike each other in an explosion that would easily deplete any special effects budget. The wizards then pick a new spell and the duel continues until one is defeated.

The triumphant wizard claims all cards his or her opponent used in the duel. After Pax, the points are tallied and one school is crowned champion!

boardgame.name: Bywater's War: The United States Battles Japan for Control of the Pacific 1926-1940
boardgame.description:
From the publisher's website:

In the late 1920s, naval analyst and former spy Hector C. Bywater wrote what today would be called a "techno-thriller." His novel described a hypothetical conflict between Japan and the USA, set in his near future, 1931. His background in naval tactics, ship design, and history made him the perfect choice to write the story, and it proved to be wildly popular. In addition to being well-written and exciting, he described many advances in naval technology, such as the rise of naval aviation. But his story was also rooted in the past (including the use of poison gas), and concluded with a Jutland-style clash between the two great fleets.

Designer Bob Eldridge has transformed Bywater's novel into a gaming supplement of 30 scenarios for Command at Sea. Ship statistics include not only real-world units like the pre-war US and Japanese battleships, but also the ships that Mr. Bywater created for his story - the Alaska-class aircraft carriers and the Nagasaki-class supersubmarine. In addition he has included scenarios for another three campaigns, each determined by different historical events in 1926, 1932, and 1939. These also feature a mix of real-world and hypothetical units, like the US Lexington class, which were planned as battlecruisers until the Washington Naval Treaty.

Contents:

- 128-page booklet including 30 scenarios and stats, grouped in four separate campaigns.
- Two counter sheets of historical, hypothetical, and fictional units.


Not included but needed for play: Command at Sea 4th Edition Rules.

Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

Alle Spiele sind Neuware und in Orginalverpackung . Alle Preise sind inklusive der gesetzlichen Mehrwertsteuer von 7% bzw. 19%.

boardgame.name: Adventure Fantasy Game (6th Revision)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The core book of Paolo Greco's Adventure Fantasy Game system, an old-school-esque take on fantasy adventuring based on David Bowman's 5More design. Aside from rules for character creation, combat, adventuring and magic, the book also includes the adventure The Temple beneath the Harga Volcano.

Free pdf updates are available at www.adventurefantasygame.com

From the introduction:
This is another fantasy adventure game. Does the world need another one? Of course!
AFG exists to run fantasy sandboxes where players are free to get involved with exploration, traveling, politics,
dungeoneering, city-life and trading as much as they want. The rules aims are the following:
• Use only six-sided dice: grab a die and roll high.
• Rules simple enough to be taught and grasped in minutes, supporting pick-up play.
• Character creation should be quick and easy, not requiring to browse and pick options from a long list.
• Other games’ materials should be straight compatible or require small adaptations. You should be able to
run material from other games very easily.
• Minimum beancounting and fiddling. No experience points to track, interminable lists of character building
options. Modifiers, both in numbers and amounts, are small.
• Interesting choices must lead to important consequences.
• Rules must have a purpose and guide the narrative. Rewards must provide a clear direction for players: desired in-game actions must be rewarded by in-game rewards.

boardgame.name: Peril
boardgame.description:
A pseudo co-op game that secretly places one player against all their friends.

Much like fabled assassins of old, one player must bide time and patiently wait for the opportune moment to strike. But should your strike fail, or you wait too long, beware the others may notice and your life be now in danger. For the others, however, a perilous fight for survival while the assassin stalks the shadows and his identity remain unknown.

In PERIL, players play cards from their hand to either save or damage the turn player, secretly attempting to identify the assassin and destroy him before he destroys them. But be weary, who you destroy could be one of your own.

boardgame.name: Agents of SMERSH: Swagman's Hope
boardgame.description:
It is all going so well for you in Tahiti - sun and surf are yours to enjoy. The Director has not troubled you with silly assignments, such as escorting ill-mannered diplomats to parties; nor have you had to drop off intelligence in trash bins to be picked up by shady, desperate officials. You've made time to rest and do little other than drink martinis... Maybe you should hang up your hat and let someone else handle Dr. Lobo?

Alas, good things never last...

"Agent, you're going to Australia," the Director informs you. "As you are well aware, Australia has descended into corruption and chaos these past several years. You won't have time for barbies on the beach."

In Agents of SMERSH: Swagman's Hope, players have five new city locations to visit and a new book, featuring more than 300 encounters, with its own Reaction Sheet. Australia is the most dangerous country in the world, so why would important persons of intellect and power be trapped there? It is up to the players to come to their aid before SMERSH gets to them. Not only must players gain the normal Yellow Intel during the course of the game, but there are new Red Intel, representing scientists and researchers with vital knowledge for which Dr Lobo is hungry. Hurry to their aid before they get abducted and taken into the lawless Swagman's Hope where they may disappear forever. Swagman's Hope is a godforsaken, desert town in the middle of the Australian Outback - a dirty haven for the criminally insane and insanely criminal.

Also included in Agents of SMERSH: Swagman's Hope are new Villain, Fate and Status Cards, a new HENCHMAN, the Stranded Deck, Red Intel and Dead Drop Tokens, and 2 new UN agents to join in the hunt. Despite the town's name, hope is in short supply. Best of luck to you, Agent.

boardgame.name: Il Domino Della Giornata
boardgame.description:
A language learning game, designed to study the conjugation of Italian verbs (both regular and irregular). With the 48 tiles the game tells the story of a day in the life of the Grilli family. Each tile has a picture on the left side and a text on the right side. In the text the verbs are all in the infinitive form, and have to be conjugated when the tile is played, but it can be checked in the instructions whether the correct form was used.
All the tiles are numbered. The game starts with the tile number 1 and based on the description tile number 2 needs to be found and so on.
The game can be played solo or in large groups (e.g. Italian classes).

boardgame.name: München
boardgame.description:
Quiz game about München (Munich) landmarks.

The board is a map of the city, with a track wandering through it. If a player is the first to land on one of the numbered spaces, he draws the card from the deck of 30 cards and reads out the information on the blue side of the card. Then he turns the card over to see what instructions he has to follow. This are fairly predictable; Miss a turn perhaps, roll the die and move backwards, and so on. The player then takes the card and keeps it in front of him where all the players can see it. The card will have a value ranging from 5 to 30, with the value being commensurate with the penalty value of the instruction on it. If a subsequent player lands on a numbered field that has already been taken, then he treats the space as a normal space without number.

When the numbered space 30 has been reached, that player has finished. The others play on. When all the players have reached the 30 space, the 'won' cards are added up and the winner is the one with the most points.

boardgame.name: Blender Bros.
boardgame.description:
User Summary by zefquaavius

Blender Bros. is a side-scrolling platform game, in which you play the role of Blender, leader of the Cosmo Keepers. Blender has enormous, prehensile ears that he can use for all sorts of purposes, including attacking, climbing, performing high-reaching ear-spring jumps, and — amazingly enough — hearing: He can listen for Mini Bros. This is where the "Bros." part of the title comes in: As you start each level, you get to select any one of the (up to twenty) Mini Bros. you have gained so far in the game as your helper for the level. Each Mini Bro. conveys a different benefit, be it extending the reach of your attacks, healing, or something else entirely.

The game has kart-style racing vignettes between some of the normal level.

boardgame.name: Catcher Quartett
World Wrestling Federation Quartett
boardgame.description:
This card game is a traditional Quartett game using the picture cards but it also has a second game that uses the backs of the cards. This game is called Catcher Quartett and is only for two players.

Each card has a wrestling move on it.The four moves are Press, Pin, Drop Kick and Body Slam.

Each player is dealt half the deck. Both players choose a card secretly and then both cards are revealed simultaneously. If they are not the same, the following applies:

PRESS beats PIN
PIN beats BODY SLAM and DROP KICK
DROP KICK beats PRESS
BODY SLAM beats DROP KICK and PRESS

The strongest card takes the weaker card. Play continues until all the cards are used and the player with the most cards wins. If you want a longer game you can continue until one player has won all the cards.

boardgame.name: Monster Memo
boardgame.description:
This is not a Memory game variation but it does require a good memory to win.

Each player takes a board on which there are a number of circles. Five of these circles show a Pancake Monster. Each player has a quantity of Pancake Tiles and these are placed on your board. The Pancake Monsters must be covered carefully so that the Monster cannot be seen.

in a turn, a player may lift up a Pancake Tile from the player on his left. If it does not reveal a Pancake Monster, the tile is taken and put on your own board. You may then continue your turn by taking a Pancake Tile from the board of the next player to your left. And so on, until a Pancake Monster is revealed. The tile must be replaced and the turn is over. Now the next player can play accordingly.

You need a good memory because it is bad to reveal a monster and as they get revealed and recovered, players should get some idea of which tile not to look under.

The first person to completely fill their board with Pancake Tiles, wins.

boardgame.name: Silent But Deadly
boardgame.description:
In Silent But Deadly, there are 10 different types of fart cards in four various colors. Each fart card has a description of the fart card, like "Fluffy Poot", "Eggy Stinker", and "Floating Biscuits". Players discard a card in his/her hand by matching a fart type or by matching the color of the card played. The goal of the game is for a player to discard all of his/her cards.

Additional 'special play' cards include, "Light a Match", "Baked Beans", "Cabbage", and "Silent But Deadly". The Light a Match card negates these three specialty cards:
--Cabbage card requires a player to the left to pick up 1 card.
--Baked Beans requires the pick up of 2 cards.
--Silent But Deadly requires picking up 5 cards.

When a player is down to one card, he/she must announce, "low on gas" before the next player discards, else he/she is penalized and must draw 2 cards.

boardgame.name: The Wiki Game
boardgame.description:
The Wiki Game is a hypertextual game designed to work specifically with Wikipedia. The Wiki Game (known casually as the "Wikipedia race") requires only a computer, Internet access, a web browser and a time-keeping device (optional) to play.
Contents

Objective

Players (one or more) start on the same randomly selected article and must navigate to another pre-selected article (home) only clicking links within the current article. The goal is to arrive at the home article in the fewest number of clicks (articles) or the least time. The single-player Wiki Game, known as Wikirace, Wikispeedia, WikiLadders, WikiClick, or WikiWhack, involves reducing one's previous time or number of clicks.

Source: Wikipedia, "Wikipedia:Wiki Game", available under the CC-BY-SA License.


The Wiki Game is folk game that is often used in schools as an educational tool.

boardgame.name: Axis & Allies Air Force Miniatures: Bandits High
boardgame.description:
Axis & Allies Air Force Miniatures is a fast, action-paced game of World War II air combat. Players take the stick of one or more of history's most famous warplanes, taking on their opponent in wild dogfights. Bandits High features aircraft used in the Pacific Theater of Operations and introduces new scenarios, including bombing missions!

Two-Player Starter Set includes six non-random warplanes, including the exclusive P-38J Lightning Ace, and everything needed to start dogfighting!

Booster Packs each contain three random warplanes, and there are 31 different planes for players to collect!

This is a game of aerial combat with WWII aircraft of various nations fought on a hexagonal map. This set represent aircraft primarily from the early years of the war. Players take turns determining initiative, moving their aircraft, and attacking opponents. Victory is determined player elimination or victory point total comparisons. Optional rules allow for clouds, flak fields, barrage balloons, and even night combat.

A&A Air Miniatures: Bandits High details:

- Set contains legendary aircraft like the Ju 87 Stuka, Navy F4U Corsair, P-51D Mustang, and IL-2 Sturmovik.
- Prepainted, durable plastic—assembled and ready to play, right out of the box.
- Abilities and statistics of units based on historical performance in battle.

boardgame.name: The Keepers of Lingusia
boardgame.description:
Back cover blurb:
Old School Swords & Sorcery Adventure in the World of Lingusia

A classic campaign setting, built on 30 years of adventuring in old school game systems, written and presented for use with modern retro-clones under the OGL 1.0a.

New Classes, monsters, kingdoms of adventure, hand-rendered old-school style maps, tons of adventure ideas, a complete pantheon of gods...

Battle for Glory in the Hyrkanian Empire...
Liberate Octzel from ancient evils...
Quest for lost kingdoms in Amech...
Discover the ruins of Corti'Zhan, city of gods...

Publisher's blurb:
The Keepers of Lingusia: A classic Old School campaign setting released under Open Game License 1.0a and designed specifically for use with Old School retrogames (and Castles & Crusades in particular). Includes classes, monsters, gods, kingdoms of adventure and many, many hand-rendered Very Very Old School style maps. For gaming the way it was! Requires an Old School rule system to play (specifically designed for Castles & Crusades by Troll Lords Publishing but also easily converted for use with OSRIC, Labyrinth Lord, Legends of the Flame Princess, Dark Dungeons, and Swords & Wizardry, among others)
From the overview:
The World of Lingusia is an immense realm, a legendary planet forged at the moment of creation by great, primal beings. Its history is one of perpetual discovery, magic, danger, and conflict. It is, in short, ideally suited for tales of high adventure, intrigue, and exploration.

User comment:
This setting is based on Tori Bergquist's personal campaign setting and there are support materials (maps and campaign notebooks) available for download. The setting has developed over thirty years of gaming and has been used with several rules systems during that time: Dungeons & Dragons, Dragonquest, Runequest, GURPS, C&C and T&T. The current, published form of the setting is designed for use with C&C. There are setting locations suggested for several TSR-era adventure modules.

The setting book features a section of house rules that have a distinct old-school flavour, the house rules section (for C&C) is also available separately.

boardgame.name: LEGO City Stories
LEGO City Undercover: The Chase Begins
boardgame.description:
"Lego City Undercover: The Chase Begins is an upcoming prequel sandbox-style action-adventure video game, currently in development by TT Fusion, a division of TT Games, that will be released on the Nintendo 3DS on April 21, 2013. Unlike previous Lego titles developed by TT Games, which have been based on various licenses, the game is based on the Lego City brand and will be published by Nintendo. It is the second Lego game to be published by Nintendo rather than an independent publisher such as WB Games or LucasArts.

Gameplay

Lego City Undercover: The Chase Begins is a City-themed video game set for release on the Nintendo 3DS on April 21, 2013. The game is a prequel to the Wii U title, Lego City Undercover, and follows the adventures of Chase McCain as a rookie cop.

Development

LEGO City Undercover: The Chase Begins was first announced during Nintendo's press conference at E3 2011 on 7 June 2011 with the tentative name LEGO City Stories. On 17 January 2013 the 3DS game was revealed to have had a name change to LEGO City Undercover: The Chase Begins"

Source: Wikipedia, "Lego City Undercover: The Chase Begins", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Family Charades In A Box Compendium
boardgame.description:
Family Charades In A Box Compendium is a party and family game of acting out. Six themes of Charades are included in one box. Themes include: Hollywood Charades, Animal Party, Time Capsule, Family Charades, Kids Charades, and Picture Charades (which requires no reading). The goal of the game is to be the first team to win the most points at the end of 12 rounds by correctly guessing the Charade(s).

The Second Edition print of Family Charades In A Box Compendium was manufactured in the United States. Components include six card decks, a sand-timer and a spinner. Each card has three Charades. The spinner determines which Charades the TEAM will act out. Choices on the spinner include acting out one of the three Charades on the card, the OTHER TEAM picking which Charade should be acted out, the TEAM chooses which Charade to act out or all three Charades must be acted out.

Rules include a signal sheet to help players act out the Charade.

boardgame.name: Mini Games: Casino
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:



Welcome to the d20 Guide to Casino Action!

There is just something about the floor of a casino, a feeling of electricity in the air. Cheers at the craps table, the clink of coins dropping from slot machines, the scream of cheaters having their hands broken ... yes, there’s something for everyone inside a casino.

This book is a guide to the most popular modern casino games to spice up your d20 campaign, whether you are playing in the fantasy genre or contemporary times. The rules are broken into two sets: abstract and detailed, depending on how detailed you would like to roleplay character time at the tables. The abstract rules are meant for simulating long stretches of casino game play, such as a character spending an evening at a poker table. The detailed rules are for when you want to play out every play – or at least the ones that matter.

The book is rounded out with a few extra casino tidbits, such as how casinos deal with cheaters in a magical world and new feats for dedicated character gamblers.

boardgame.name: Gazala
Gazala 1942
boardgame.description:
Gazala is a low complexity wargame on the Battle of Gazala. The game can be played either solitaire or with two players.

Each player has an objective that they must meet in order to win - either number of units destroyed or occupying certain hexes. Each counter can move one hex per turn. The combat is a simple system in which the players must roll greater than or equal to the number printed on the counter to achieve a hit.

The rules are only three pages long. The game also includes a counter sheet and a map that can be printed at 11x17 (A3) or 8.5x11 (A4).
